Reassure patient that he does not have and disease

questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ref.: Harrison's priciples of interrnal medicine 19/e p 2039, Chapter 362

choices.text: Pregnant woman with sore throat can be started immediately on oseltamivir without diagnostic testing under category B
People on long term steroids cannot receive oseltamivir
Category B concerns with low risk cases
Category B patients have to undergo immediate testing

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding H1N1 influenza
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) INFLUENZA H1N1 guidelines Category- A • Patients with mild fever plus cough / sore throat with or without bodyache, headache, diarrhoea and vomiting will be categorized as Category-A. They do not require Oseltamivir and should be treated for the symptoms mentioned above. The patients should be monitored for their progress and reassessed at 24 to 48 hours by the doctor. • No testing of the patient for Influenza is required. • Patients should confine themselves at home and avoid mixing up with public and high risk members in the family. Category-B (i) In addition to all the signs and symptoms mentioned under Category-A, if the patient has high grade fever and severe sore throat, may require home isolation and Oseltamivir; (ii) In addition to all the signs and symptoms mentioned under Category-A, individuals having one or more of the following high risk conditions shall be treated with Oseltamivir: • Children with mild illness but with predisposing risk factors. • Pregnant women; • Persons aged 65 years or older; • Patients with lung diseases, heart disease, liver disease kidney disease, blood disorders, diabetes, neurological disorders, cancer and HIV/AIDS; • Patients on long term cortisone therapy. • No tests for Influenza is required for Category-B (i) and (ii). • All patients of Category-B (i) and (ii) should confine themselves at home and avoid mixing with public and high risk members in the family. • Broad Spectrum antibiotics as per the Guideline for Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) may be prescribed. Category-C In addition to the above signs and symptoms of Category-A and B, if the patient has one or more of the following: • Breathlessness, chest pain, drowsiness, fall in blood pressure, sputum mixed with blood, bluish discolouration of nails; • Children with influenza like illness who had a severe disease as manifested by the red flag signs (Somnolence, high and persistent fever, inability to feed well, convulsions, shortness of breath, difficulty in breathing, etc). • Worsening of underlying chronic conditions. All these patients mentioned above in Category-C require testing, immediate hospitalization and treatment.

questions.text: Most common type of nephropathy associated with malignancy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Membranous nephropathy maybe associated with solid organ tumours, lympho-proliferative states, auto-immune disease and chronic infections. Ref.: Harrison's Principles of internal medicene 19/ 1844-1845

questions.text: Which of the following do not usually cause reduction in diffusion lung capacity of carbon monoxide
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • The DLCO measures the ability of the lungs to transfer gas from inhaled air to the red blood cells in pulmonary capillaries Decreases in : DLCO is decreased in any condition which affects the effective alveolar surface area: • Hindrance in the alveolar wall. e.g. fibrosis, alveolitis, vasculitis • Decrease of total lung area, e.g. Restrictive lung disease or lung resection (partial or total). • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (Emphysema) due to decreased surface area in the alveoli, as well as damage to the capillary bed • Pulmonary embolism • Cardiac insufficiency • Pulmonary hypertension • Bleomycin (upon administration of more than 200 units) • Chronic heart failure • Anemia-due to decrease in blood volume • Amiodarone high cumulative dose; more than 400 milligrams per day • After chemotherapy and radiotherapy Increases in :Factors that can increase the DLCO • Polycythaemia • asthma (can also have normal DLCO) • increased pulmonary blood volume as occurs in exercise.

questions.text: Best antihypertensive drug in pulmonary hypertension
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (UPDATE–Ambrisentan–once daily endothelin receptor antagonist is preferred over Bosentan ) Ref.: Harrison's Priniples of internal medicine 19/e p 1655

questions.text: In a patient of mitral stenosis, decreased 1st heart sound is seen in all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mitral stenosis heart sounds In the initial stages of the condition, the first heart sound S1 is frequently accentuated. Loud S1 in MS is independent of MS severity. The anterior mitral valve leaflet's distance to return to its annular plane, leaflet mobility, left ventricular contractility, and the PR interval all affect S1 intensity. Causes of loud S1 include: Tachycardia Increased AV flow Prolonged AV flow Short PR interval

questions.text: An obese diabetic patient was on metformin monotherapy, but his sugar levels were not well controlled. He is allergic to sulpha drugs and does not comply to injectables. He has history of pancreatitis, and family history of bladder CA. In view of the raised glucose levels, you wish to add another anti – diabetic drug. Which one would you prefer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ref.: Harrison's Priniples of internal medicine 19/e Pg 2414

questions.text: What is the drug given for management of anaphylactic shock?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Epinephrine 1:1,000 dilution, 0.2 to 0.5 mL (0.2 to 0.5 mg) in adults, or 0.01 mg per kg in children, should be injected subcutaneously or intramuscularly in anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Tumor lysis syndrome does not have
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is characterized by hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia and is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. Acidosis may also develop. Acute renal failure occurs frequently. TLS is most often associated with the treatment of Burkitt’s lymphoma, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, and other rapidly proliferating lymphomas, but it also may be seen with chronic leukemias and, rarely, with solid tumors. This syndrome has been seen in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia after treatment with nucleosides like fludarabine. TLS has been observed with administration of glucocorticoids,hormonal agents such as letrozole and tamoxifen, and monoclonal antibodies such as rituximab and gemtuzumab. TLS usually occursduring or shortly (1–5 days) after chemotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in the acute management of Hyperkalemia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Treatment of Hyperkalemia: 1st line agent – Glucose-Insulin drip 2. Calcium Gluconate infusion – Cardio-Protection. 3. B2-agonist – most common Albuterol. 4. In Refractory cases – Hemodialysis. (HD is most effective and Reliable method to lower Potassium) Note : IV soda Bicarbonate has no role in management of acute Hyperkalemia. Ref : Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 19e/pg.312 : Treatment of Hyperkalemia

questions.text: The ECG image was given. What is the finding seen in this ECG.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Total electrical alternans (P-QRS-T) with sinus tachycardia is a relatively specific sign of pericardial effusion, usually with cardiac tamponade .The mechanism relates to a periodic swinging motion of the heart in the effusion at a frequency exactly one half the heart rate.

questions.text: A patient presented with headache, fever, neck rigidity. The Brudzinski and Kernig’s sign were positive. The CSF analysis showed the following picture: Which is the causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref.: Harrison's Priniples of internal medicine 19/e pg 890-893 • Coxackie virus belongs to Enteroviruses (EV).Enetroviruses are the most common cause of viral meningitiscan be identified. • Cases may either be sporadic or occur in clusters. • Enteroviruses are the most likely cause of viral meningitis in the summer and fall months,especially in children (95%) and specific (>100%). CSF PCR has the highest sensitivity if performed within 48 h of symptom onset, with sensitivity declining rapidly after day 5 of symptoms. • PCR of throat washings or stool specimens may be positive for several weeks, and positive results can help support the diagnosis of an acute enteroviral infection

questions.text: A 17-years-old boy with complaints of difficulty in breathing. There was venous congestion of face and neck. And a clinical diagnosis of svc syndrome was made. The X-ray showed mediastinal widening. What is next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref.: Harrison's Priniples of internal medicine 19/e pg 1787 Superior venavaca syndrome Plain radiograph Indirect signs on chest x-ray, such as superior mediastinal widening and right hilar prominence that may indicate the presence of mediastinal mass. CT Is the imaging modality of choice. Enhanced CT shows the location and severity of the SVC obstruction, superimposed thrombosis, a mediastinal mass or lymphadenopathy, collateral vessels and associated lung masses.

questions.text: All of the following are cause of metabolic acidosis with normal anion Gap Except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ref.: Harrison's Priniples of internal medicine 19/e pg 317-320 Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis • Diarrhea • Renal tubular acidosis • Adrenal insufficiency • Chronic kidney disease • Intestinal, pancreatic, biliary fistula • Hypoaldosteronism • Spironolactone, prostaglandin inhibitors, triamterene, amiloride, trimethoprim, pentamidine, cyclosporin

questions.text: A Patient had proptosis and hypotropia, which was relieved within 5 mins of administering n IV drug. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref.: Harrison's Priniples of internal medicine 19/e pg 2701-2705 Anticholinesterase Test Drugs that inhibit the enzyme AChE allow ACh to interact repeatedly with the limited number of AChRs in MG, producing improvement in muscle strength. Edrophonium is used most commonly for diagnostic testing because of the rapid onset (30 s) and short duration (~5 min) of its effect. An objective end point must be selected to evaluate the effect of edrophonium, such as weakness of extraocular muscles, impairment of speech, or the length of time that the patient can maintain the arms in forward abduction.

questions.text: A patient came with early diastolic murmur in the second intercostal space and had differential BP recording in the upper limb with one arm showing measurement of 150/110 mm Hg and the other showing 90/60. All of the following can be a cause Except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ref.: Harrison's Priniples of internal medicine 19/e 1530 Supravalvular aortic stenosis This is a localized or diffuse narrowing of the ascending aorta originating just above the level of the coronary arteries at the superior margin of the sinuses of Valsalva. In most patients, a genetic defect for the anomaly is located in the same chromosomal region as elastin on chromosome 7.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best guide for fluid administration?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Urine output is the best and non-invasive method of calculating fluid requirement.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaint of headache and describes it as the worst headache of his life, though there is no focal deficit. What should be the next investigation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The above symptom :” worst headache of my life” signifies thunderclap headache. This is a symptom of spontaneous sub arachnoid haemorrhage. The investigation of choice is non contrast CT scan of head.

questions.text: Which of these factors is not used to assess the reliability of the relative while taking history?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) While taking a history from a relative or caregiver, clinicians assess the reliability of the informant based on factors that affect their ability to accurately observe, recall, and report the patient’s condition. Blood relation alone does not determine reliability, as being a family member does not necessarily mean the person is observant, educated, or aware of the patient's behavior. A. Time of cohabitation Explanation: This does affect reliability — someone who has lived with the patient for a longer time is more likely to have direct and frequent observation of the patient’s behavior, making them a more reliable informant. C. Education status Explanation: An informant’s education level can influence their ability to understand questions, communicate effectively, and report symptoms accurately, which directly impacts reliability. D. Observational ability Explanation: This is a core factor in assessing reliability. A person who is naturally more observant and attentive will provide a more accurate history, regardless of their relationship to the patient.

questions.text: SAAG>1.1% in all case of ascites Except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ref.: Harrison's Priniples of internal medicine 19/e Pg. 287, Chapter 59.

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin 7.2 million units in three divided doses
Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units single dose
Benzyl penicillin 12-24 million units for 21 days

questions.text: Treatment of choice for late cardiovascular syphilis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Treatment of syphilis: • Primary/ secondary/ early latent syphilis: benzathine penicillin 2.4mU single dose • Tertiary/ late latent syphilis: benzathine penicillin 2.4 mU weekly for three doses • Neurosyphillis ( asymptomatic/ symptomatic) : penicillin G 18 to 20 mU/day for 10 to 14 days

choices.text: Heberden nodes on pre-existing osteo arthritis
Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints
Post traumatic dystrophy with Complex regional pain syndrome

questions.text: A woman presents with pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand. There were associated complaints of Morning stiffness with problem in squatting. The swelling spared the DIP joints. The image of the patient’s hands is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Morning stiffness with sparing of DIP joints suggests the diagnosis to be rheumatoid arthritis. Swan nck deformity, Z deformity, boutonniere’s deformity is seen in rheumatoid artritis • CharactersticDIP involvement is seen in osteoarthritis, reiters arthritis and psoriatic arthritis

questions.text: A 22-years-old man presents with diarrhea and intolerance to dairy products, on investigation he was found to have lactase deficiency. Agent least likely to cause lactose intolerance among these is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Yoghurt is the least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance. It contains lactobacillus that produces lactase and is generally well tolerated . Lactase is a brush border enzyme that hydrolyzes lactose into glucose and galactose . In lactase deficiency, patients have great variability in clinical symptoms ,depending on both the severity of lactase deficiency and the amount of lactose ingested . Lactose intolerance is known to cause osmotic diarrhoea. Important feature of osmotic diarrhoea is it presents with • abdominal distention with pain abdomen • stops with fasting • stool osmotic gap is more than 50 treatment is to avoid milk and milk products. Among the above options, the least likely to cause lactose intolerance is yoghurt.

questions.text: A known 60-years-old male diabetic and hypertensive patient was found unconscious in the morning. On examination pulse-120, bp-180/100 and there was positive extensor plantar. What is next step to be done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Pulse >120 suggests sympathetic overactivity. • Sympathetic overactivity with B/L etensor plantar reflex suggests hypoglycaemia • Hence the next step will be to check blood glucose.

choices.text: HBsAg, IgM antiHBC, AntiHDV, AntiHCV, AntiHEV

questions.text: 40-years-malepatient who was a known smoker presents in AIIMS OPD with fever, fatigue, jaundice, yellow colored urine with clay colored stools. For the past few days he had developed aversion to cigarette smoking. On examination scleral icterus was present. LFT are: What investigations will you send for ruling out acute viral hepatitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Three serologies to be done to confirm hepatitis are • For HepA: IgM anti hepA • For hep B: HbsAg + IgM anti HBC • For hep C:anti HCV • For hep E:anti HEV

questions.text: ‘A’ wave in JVP Indicates
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Waves in JVP • A wave: atrial contraction • C wave: tricuspid cusps bulging into right atria during isovolumetric contraction • X decent: tricuspid ring pulled down by chordae tendinae • V wave: atrial filling • Y decent: atrial blood emptying into right ventricle

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the ECG given below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Absent p wave wit irregular heart rate suggests AF

questions.text: A patient is having Ph-7.12, HCO3-28 and PCO2-50mmhg. What is the acid bas disorder in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • pH is low and PaCO2 is high. Since they are going in opposite direction, it must be respiratory acidosis. • Compensatory HCO3 is 24 + (10 x 0.1) = 28. Hence it is compensated.

questions.text: A female patient was brought to the ER with altered sensorium. On examination BP was 88/67mm with a pulse of 60/min. Rectal temperature was 340. There was associated history of constipation, dry skin and menorrhagia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Clinical features given above suggests hypothyroidism.This patient is having myxedema coma. It is managed by giving intravenous levothyroxine 500micrograms bolus. Mortality is 20 to 40%

choices.text: A rare complication of Rapid and aggressive sodium correction

questions.text: An old lady developed intractable vomiting for 7 days with loss of fluid in stools, decrease food intake and developed altered sensorium. She is brought to the hospital, where fluid loss is corrected with rapid fluids and electrolyte correction is given for hyponatremia. During the treatment, the patient started having quadriplegia and mutism. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The complication given above occurs due to rapid sodium correction. This ocuurs due to pontine myelinolysis syndrome. All the pyramidal fbres coming from above are damage. Due to cranial nerve paralysis it causes LMN features of cranial nerves arising from pons. This condition is irreversible. Hence prevention of rapid sodium correction has to be done. Ideal rate of correction of sodium is not more than 10mmol/L for 24 hrs.

questions.text: A healthy middle-aged man was arguing with his brother and got emotionally upset due to the arguments with his brother, he suddenly developed chest pain and collapsed. When brought to the hospital, he was declared dead. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Suddenchest pain after emotional stress is due to takotsubo cardiomyopathy. This is also known as stress cardiomyopathy, broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome. Is is more common in females aged around 50 yrs . ST elevation can be seen on ECG and troponin levels are elevated. Treatment is conservative.

questions.text: A patient presented with headache and fever for 7 days. While doing a lumbar puncture, it was noticed that the opening CSF pressure increased on jugular vein compression and became normal on relieving the pressure on jugular vein. What is the interpretation of this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Changes in CSF pressure on changing pressure on jugular vein suggests patent subarachnoid space.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever for 8 days and difficulty in breathing for two days, on examination there is red painless rash found on the left side of the chest. Treatment will be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) An eschar is black, necrotic and painless tissue, often observed on the chest and is usually linked to Rickettsial infections. Doxycycline is usually the go-to drug for treating Rickettsial infections since the microbes lack cell wall components that makes beta-lactams and cephalosporins ineffective.

questions.text: A patient of RTA presents in emergency with inability to speak. On examination, the patient was moaning with inability to speak but patient was able to understand what he wanted to speak. Which of the following marked area of brain is involved in this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The marked area is Broca’s area which is located in inferior frontal gyrus. Damage to this area leads to broca’s aphasia

questions.text: A known case of syphilis unable to walk with eyes closed and walks with stamping the foot on ground. Which tract involved
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Syphilis causes myelopathy known as TABES DORSALIS It affects posterior column in spinal cord which carries vibration sense, joint position sense and fine touch. • With Loss of vibration sense , the person is unable to feel the floor while walking. Inorder to feel the floor , the person hits his foot hard on the floor resulting in stamping gait. • Loss of proprioception or joint position sense leads to swaying when he closes his eyes. This is known as rombergs sign +ve

questions.text: A patient presents with history of urinary incontinence with soiling of clothes and he has no guilt of the above action. Which of the following lobes are affected?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Social inhibition on bladder/ micturition is maintained by frontal lobe area and para central lobule. These areas send impulses to pons which is the actual micturition center. Ponssends impulses down the spinal cord for either contraction or relaxation of bladder. If frontal lobe is affected, the social inhibition on bladder is lost. This condition is called infant bladder.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be diagnosed if ANA is negative?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SLE ANA test is the most sensitive test done in SLE.

questions.text: A patient has Recurrent optic neuritis with myelitis and episode were relieved by steroid use. Which is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Neuromyelitis optics also known as Devic’s disease • Female to male ratio is 3: 1 • Occurs in adulthood • Symtoms of optic neuritis are often bilateral and severe • Myelitis is severe and known as transverse myelitis. 3 or 4 longitudinal segments are involved • Pathology: antibodies against Aquaporin 4 channels which are IgG type • CSF findings: pleocytosis, NO oligoclonal bands • It is an astrocytopathy • Treatment:IV Methy prednisolone 1gm/day for 5 days. Later changed to oral dose • Prophylaxis: Mycophenolate moefetil and rituximab

questions.text: Diagnosis on the below ECG?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Irregular heart rate with tachycardia suggests two diagnosis ie multifocal atrial tachycardia or atrial fibrillation. • P waves are absent in atrial fibrillation. • In the above image, P waves are present with more than two morphologieswhich points towards Multifocal atrial tachycardia

questions.text: A 16 year boy presented with steatorrhea. Schilling test +ve, Normal d xylulose. Duodenal biopsy normal. Diagnosis is –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Ileal disease: Shillings test positive suggestsabnormal B12 absorption in ileum .Steatorrea ie fat malabsorption also occurs in ileal disease. • Coeliac diease: it affects proximal intestine. D Xylulose test will be abnormal • Ulcerative colitis doesn’t affect small intestine, hence doesn’t present as steatorrhoea

choices.text: Stop medicine and do 6 monthly EEG

questions.text: 16 year had seizures during sleep, started on drugs. No further episode after 6 months. EEG was normal, other investigations are also normal .Which is the next appropriate step in the management of the patient
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Anti epileptics must be continued for a minimum of two years of seizure free interval before tapering the dose and stopping the drug.

questions.text: A brain cut section as shown below, has injury in the marked area. Which of the following will not happen when the marked structure is damaged?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Damage to the paracentral lobule can cause: A. Urinary incontinence → Yes, due to involvement of the micturition center. B. Bowel incontinence → Yes, due to cortical control of voluntary defecation. C. Paraesthesia perianally → Yes, because the sensory cortex for the perianal area lies in this region (near the medial surface). D. Gait Apraxia: Not caused by paracentral lobule damage. Gait apraxia is due to frontal lobe (especially frontal subcortical white matter) or basal ganglia dysfunction. It involves difficulty initiating walking, with a magnetic or shuffling gait, despite preserved strength and coordination.

choices.text: Needle to be punctured at 45 degrees

questions.text: What is wrong about the procedure of ABG?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Wrist is slightly extended before taking ABG sample

choices.text: High anion gap Metabolic Acidosis + Metabolic Alkalosis

questions.text: A know patient of CKD presents to the emergency with vomiting stains pH=7.4 Bicarb=24 Pco2=40 Na=145 chloride=100 What is the metabolic abnormality??
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Step 1 : the pH being 7.4 is within normal limits Step 2 : Plama HCO3- is 24mEq/L and again is still within normal limits Step 3 : Calculating anion gap : Anion Gap : ( Na+ ) - { ( CL-) + ( HCO3-)} = 145 - ( 100+24) = 21 A High anion gap indicates Metabolic acidosis. However HCO3- levels within normal limits suggest that there is also co-existing metabolic Alkalosis in this patient . This can be confirmed by Delta Gap Delta Gap: ? AG -? HCO3- = (21-10 ) - (24-24) = +11 Delta Gap : >+6 : High anionic Gap Metabolic acidosis+ Metabolic Alkalosis -6 to +6 : High Anionic Gap Metabolic acidosis <-6 : High anion gap Metabolic Acidosis and non anionic Gap Metabolic acidosis. This can also be confirmed by Delta ratio : ( Not possible in this question)

choices.text: Acute respiratory acidosis & Chronic respiratory alkalosis

questions.text: In the below Davenport diagram what will happen if the curve shifts towards left of normal?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The Davenport diagram shows shifts in pH at various levels of arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2) Chronic respiratory acidosis: Fall in pH Rise in pCO2 Rise in HCO3 Metabolic acidosis: Fall in pH Fall in HCO3

choices.text: No intervention as ct is normal

questions.text: A 55-year-old person brought to the casualty with a history of TIA and now presents with left sided facial weakness. CT is clear, BP – 160/110 mm HG. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) IV thrombolysis is done with rTPA. Contra indications of thrombolysis are • BP > 185/110 inspite of anti hypertensive therapy • Bleeding diasthesis • Recent head injury or intra cerebral bleed • Any GI bleed in last 21 days • Any major surgery in last 14 days • Recent MI Indications of thrombolysis • Onset ? 4.5hrs • If MCA infarct ± edema <1/3rd of its own territory • Age above 18 yrs

questions.text: Which of the following will help us to differentiate cardiac tamponade from tension pneumothorax
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Common features between cardiac tamponade and pneumothorax is • Hypotension • Raised JVP Cardiac tamponade presents with muffled heart sounds where as pneumothorax presents with reduced/ absent breath sounds

choices.text: 6 drugs for 6 months then 4 drugs x 18 months
6 drugs x 4 months then 4 drug x 12 months
7 drug x 2 month then 6 drugs for 1 month then 5 drugs x 5 months
7 drugs for 1 month then 6 drugs for 2 months then 5 drugs for 5 months

questions.text: Resistance to INH and rifampicin – treatment
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) MDR – TB Initiation phase: 6 drugs x 6 to 9 months Continuation phase: 4 drugs x 18 months Total duration : 24 to 27 months

questions.text: ECG with "mean" axis of 90°. In which lead there would be the maximum voltage of R wave?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: While measuring blood pressure of a cardiac tamponade patient, what advice will you give him
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Most common cause of pulses paradoxus is cardiac tamponade. This will be checked in his /her basal breathing. No other breathing instructions will be given.

questions.text: Relative bradycardia not seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Malaria Causes of relative bradycardia • Typhoid fever • Factitious fever • Brucella • Legionella • Viral fevers Malaria rarely can cause relative brady cardia. Here this becomes the best answer.

questions.text: The lung volume compliance curve is shown below. Which of the following will fit in the marked graph B?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: A patient on warfarin presents with major bleeding and found to have PT INR of 1.5. How much fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is required to treat this situation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Adult Dose of FFP is 15ml/kg 1 FFP unit = 271 ml of FFP

questions.text: A 70-years-old patient presents with dizziness and headache followed by left sided hemiparesis with right eye dilatation and ptosis. Most probable blood vessel damaged is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Right eye dialatation and ptosis suggest : LMN of III cranial nerve on ipsilateral side • Left sided hemiparesis suggests lesion of contralateral side • Lesion is said to be in brainstem which is supplied by posterior cerebral artery

questions.text: What is the site of lesion in a patient with Alexia without agraphia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Alexia means inability to respond to visual input. This occurs due to a lesion in left occipital cortex and posterior sector of corpus callosum (splenuim).

questions.text: Differential diagnosis for ‘Thunderclap headache’ are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Thunderclap headache is a severe explosive headache which has maximum peak at onset (<1 min). Causes of thunderclap headache are • Subarachnoid hemorrage • Internal carotid artery dissection • Cerebral venous thrombosis

questions.text: A patient with undulating fever presents with features of encephalitis. He is treated successfully with doxycycline and rifampicin. Probable diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Undulant fever: An infectious disease due to the bacteria Brucella that characteristically causes rising and falling fevers, sweats, malaise, weakness, anorexia, headache, myalgia (muscle pain) and back pain.treated with doxycycline and rifampicin.

choices.text: Morning stiffness more than equal to 1 hour
Involvement of neck, shoulder, back for more than 6 months in a year

questions.text: Which is not included in Polymyalgia rheumatic criteria (Healey criteria)?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Polymyalgia rheumatic is associated with giant cell arteritis. Criteria is i. Age > 50 yrs ii. ESR > 40 iii. Musculoskeletal pain >1 month iv. ?2 area involved in pain among neck/ shoulder/ pelvic girdle v. Morning stiffness >1hr vi. Rapid response to steroids vii. Exclusion of rheumatoid arthritis

choices.text: X-ray features upper lobe predominant in chronic HP

questions.text: A patient presents with cough with expectoration. Diagnosis of farmers lung is suspected. True statement regarding this condition:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Farmers lung is a form of hypersensitivity pneumonitis which presents as dry cough. Hence expectoration and pleural effusion are not seen. There is apical sparing in this condition, hence there will be no involvement of upper lobes.

questions.text: In revised guideline for Behcet’s disease, which criterion carries 2 points?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following diseases doesn’t cause lung cavitation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Silicosis Causes of lung cavitations are • Infectious causes: all infections can cause lung cavities except : viral causes, Streptococcal infections except serotype 3, Mycoplasma • Non- infectious causes: i) Ca lung: squamous cell Ca > small cell Ca ii) Wegeners granulomatosis iii) Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis iv) Pulmonary embolism

questions.text: Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome associated with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Birthoggdube syndrome is a hereditary condition which causes i. Benign skin tumours ii. Lung cysts iii. Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: Wavelength highly sensitive to porphyria:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (b) he porphyria diseases are a group of metabolic disorders caused by abnormal functioning of heme biosynthesis enzymes and characterized by the excessive accumulation and excretion of porphyrins and their precursors. Precisely which of these chemicals builds up depends on the type of porphyria. Porphyria is not a single disease but a group of nine disorders: acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), hereditary coproporphyria (HCP), variegate porphyria (VP), delta-aminolevelunic acid dehyratase deficiency porphyria (ADP), porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), hepatoerythropoetic porphyria (HEP), congenital erythropoetic porphyria (CEP), erythropoetic protoporphyria (EPP), and X-linked protoporphyria (XLP). Each porphyria results from overproduction of heme precursors secondary to partial deficiency or, in XLP, increased activity of one of the enzymes of heme biosynthesis.

questions.text: What is the cause of pruritis in primary biliary cholangitis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are a class of proteins that play a key role in the innate immune system. They are single, membrane-spanning, non-catalytic receptors usually expressed on sentinel cells such as macrophages and dendritic cells, that recognize structurally conserved molecules derived from microbes. Once these microbes have reached physical barriers such as the skin or intestinal tract mucosa, they are recognized by TLRs, which activate immune cell responses.TheFarnesoid X receptor (FXR) is a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily and has emerged as a key player in the control of multiple metabolic pathways. On its activation by bile acids, FXR regulates bile acid synthesis, conjugation, and transport, as well as various aspects of lipid and glucose metabolism.vanilloid receptors transduction of noxious chemical and thermal stimuli by peripheral nociceptors. TRPV1 is a non-selective cation channel gated by noxious heat, vanilloids and extracellular protons. TRPV1 channel activity is remarkably potentiated by pro-inflammatory agents, a phenomenon that is thought to underlie the peripheral sensitisation of nociceptors that leads to thermal hyperalgesia.GRP stimulates the release of gastrin from the G cells of the stomach.

questions.text: True about lung contusion is all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lung contusion (LC) is caused by blunt chest trauma, explosion injuries or a shock wave associated with penetrating trauma. These injuries damage alveolar capillaries, so blood and other fluids accumulate in the lung tissue, but it does not involve a cut or a tear of the lung tissue. The excess fluid interferes with gas exchange leading to hypoxia.Clinically, patients have hypoxiemia, hypercarbia and increase in labored breathing of varying severity and duration [7]. Patients are treated with supplemental oxygen and mechanical ventilation as necessary.50-60% of patients with significant pulmonary contusions develop bilateral ARDS. Most significant pulmonary contusions are diagnosed on plain chest X-ray, but the chest X-ray often underestimate the size of contusion and usually lags behind the clinical picture. Sometimes the true extent of contusion is not apparent on plain film until 24-48 hours following injury. Computed tomography(CT) is very sensitive for diagnosing pulmonary contusion, its size and 3-dimensional assessment.

questions.text: Regarding Polyoma BK virus, which of the following statements are true?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) It may cause hemorrhagic cystitis Explanation of Each Option: A. It affects 20-30% of renal transplant patients: This is partially true, but not the most accurate answer. The BK virus can indeed affect renal transplant recipients, but the actual prevalence is variable. It is generally reported that 5–10% of renal transplant patients may develop BK virus nephropathy, not 20–30%. B. Foscarnet is used for treatment: This is incorrect. The first-line treatment for BK virus-related complications in kidney transplant recipients typically involves leflunomide (and sometimes sirolimus) to reduce the viral load. Foscarnet is generally used for cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections, not for BK virus infections. So, B is not the correct answer. C. In children, it causes in general fever, malaise: This is not correct in the context of BK virus. While BK virus can cause mild symptoms, including fever and malaise, it tends to primarily affect immunocompromised patients (like kidney transplant recipients) rather than healthy children. The virus is not typically associated with significant clinical disease in healthy children. This makes C somewhat misleading in this context. D. It may cause hemorrhagic cystitis: This is the correct answer. BK virus is well known to cause hemorrhagic cystitis, especially in patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). This is because HSCT recipients often have severely suppressed immune systems, which increases the risk of BK virus reactivation, leading to hemorrhagic cystitis. While it can also cause nephropathy in kidney transplant recipients, hemorrhagic cystitis is a hallmark complication in HSCT patients.

questions.text: A patient presented with recurrent hemoptysis. Vessel which should be evaluated for angiography include?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In patients with recurrent hemoptysis, angiographic evaluation is often needed to locate and control the bleeding source. While most cases of hemoptysis are due to bleeding from the bronchial arteries (which are systemic arteries), when those aren't listed among the options, the pulmonary artery is the next most relevant vessel. Pulmonary artery abnormalities such as pulmonary arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) can cause significant hemoptysis and require angiographic assessment. Thus, among the given choices, pulmonary artery is the most appropriate vessel to evaluate. B. Pulmonary vein Explanation: Pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood from the lungs to the left atrium. They are not typically involved in bleeding and are not evaluated in angiography for hemoptysis. C. Brachial artery Explanation: This artery supplies the upper limb, not the lungs. It is unrelated to pulmonary circulation and has no role in hemoptysis evaluation. D. Brachial vein Explanation: The brachial vein also serves the upper limb and has no anatomical or clinical connection to pulmonary bleeding or hemoptysis. E. Superior vena cava Explanation: The superior vena cava drains venous blood from the upper body into the heart. It is not a source of bleeding into the airways and is not a target during angiographic workup for hemoptysis.

questions.text: True about Weil’s disease is/are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Weils disease is icterohemorrhagic fever caused by leptospira. Icteric leptospirosis may mimic viral hepatitis and haemorrhagic form can mimic other haemorrhagic fevers. The usual incubation period is one to two weeks, but could be in the range of 2 to 30 days. Vascular endothelial damage is the primary lesion and this leads to capillary leakage,haemorrhage, vasculitis and localised ischaemia in organs. Insevere disease coagulation cascade is activated leading todisseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Pro-inflammatory cytokines released as a result of immune-killing of leptospires mediate tissue inflammation and damage. TNF-? is also believed to play a key role in disease progression. The leptospiraemic phase begins with remittent fever (38°C to 40°C), chills, rigors, headache, myalgias, nausea and vomiting.The immune phase, which coincides with the appearance of antibodies and disappearance of the organisms from blood, is characterised by manifestations of organ dysfunctions. Pathogenic strains of leptospira are susceptible to a range of anti-microbial drugs including penicillins, cephalosporins, carbapenems, tetracyclines, macrolides and fluoroquinolones.

questions.text: All are true about SIADH except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) SIADH occurs as a result of overproduction of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH) or ADH-like substance by the tumour. Drugs like vincristine, cisplatin and cyclophosphamide may also cause SIADH. The cardinal features of SIADH are water intoxication and hyponatraemia including decreased serum osmolality, euvolaemia, inappropriate elevation of urine osmolality with elevated urine sodium with normal renal, thyroid and adrenal function. Many patients are asymptomatic. Those with sodium level of <125 mEq/L and developing hyponatraemia rapidly are more likely to be symptomatic. Water restriction (500 to 1000 mL per day) is the most important measure in treating SIADH. Hypertonic saline and diuretics are reserved for patients who have life-threatening convulsions or coma. It is important to raise the sodium level gradually. Demeclocycline is used for patients where fluid restriction and treatment of the malignancy are ineffective.

This results in dysfunction of transmembrane conductance regulatory protein (CFTR). It functions as chloride channel .it presents as • RS : sinusitis, nasal polyps, cough, crackels and wheeze, clubbing • GIT: malnutrition( absence of pancreatic enzymes), anemia, dry skin, hepatosplenomegaly, constipation, meconium ileus • Reproductive system: congenital bilateral absent vas • Investigation of choice is elevated sweat chloride levels > 60mEq. Additional tests include : CFTR gene analysis, altered ion transport across nasal epithelium. • Treatment includes : recent drugs to modulate genetic defects i) Ivacaftor : G551-D mutation ( class III mutation) ii) Lumacaftor – ivacaftor ( class II ?F508) iii) Tezacaftor – ivacaftor( class II ?F508)

questions.text: How can we clinically measure oxygen content of blood in a patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, E) Arterial Oxygen Content (CaO2) CaO2 = (1.34 x Hgb xSaO2/100 )+ (0.0031 x Pa02) 1.34 : Oxygen combining capacity in "ml 02 / g Hgb" Hgb : Hemoglobin concentration in "g Hgb/ 100 ml blood" Sa02 : Arterial Hgb that is saturated with oxygen in decimal 0.0031 : Solubility coefficient of oxygen in "vol% / mmHg" Pa02 : Partial pressure of oxygen in "mmHg"

questions.text: True about multiple sclerosis is/are?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B, C, E) MS is the most common inflammatory-demyelinating disease of the CNS and the most frequent cause of non-traumatic neurologic disability in young and middle-aged adults. Four clinical types of MS have been described: 1. Relapsing/remitting MS (RRMS) – accounts for 85% of cases at onset and is characterised by discrete attacks with often complete recovery over ensuing weeks to months. 2. Secondary progressive MS (SPMS) – always begins as RRMS.At some point, however, the clinical course changes so that the patient experiences a steady deterioration in function associated with acute attacks. For a patient with RRMS, the risk of developing SPMS is ~2.5% each year. 3. Primary progressive MS (PPMS) – accounts for ~15% of cases.These patients experience a steady functional decline from onset. 4. Progressive/relapsing MS (PRMS) – accounts for ~5% cases.These patients experience a steady deterioration from disease onset, along with occasional attacks super-imposed. TREATMENT • Interferon beta • Glatiramir acetate • Mitoxantrone ( useful in secondary progressive MS) • Natalizumab • Fingolimod • Teriflunomide • Daflampridine ( improves walking) • Dimetyly fumarate • Ocrelizumab ( useful in primary progressive MS)

This is seen mainly from penetrating injuries to the cord though partial lesions are more common than classical pattern.

questions.text: In wilsons disease, there is urinary excretion of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Wilson disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by excess copper stored in various body tissues, particularly the liver, brain, and corneas of the eyes. The disease is progressive and, if left untreated, it may cause liver (hepatic) disease, central nervous system dysfunction, and death. Early diagnosis and treatment may prevent serious long-term disability and life threatening complications. Wilson disease is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait. Wilson disease is caused by disruption or changes (mutations) of the ATP7B gene, which plays an important role in the movement of excess copper from the liver to the bile to eventually be excreted from the body through the intestines. More than 300 different mutations of the ATP7B gene have been identified.
